channel.title: Enums
channel.description: Does anyone know a great Enum tutorial. That breaks them down for me?

item.title: Enums
item.dc:creator: @imsuperman05 imsuperman05
item.description:
@imsuperman05 wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:37, topic:424052”][quote author=imsuperman05 link=topic=526702.msg3839578#msg3839578 date=1323130099]

That’s perfectly good, but they will run into the same issue using a map that can store null values. I was merely pointing out that their solution is flawed insomuch as the original procedure.

I agree. I just find the lack of input validation in the forums to be shocking. In fact, if there was even slight input validation for the packets being read from the client, most of the duping bugs would be removed.

An entirely separate issue. We could go back and forth for hours years centuries regarding the logic errors and design flaws in the MoparScape servers.

The amount of design flaws they make is older than their own existence!

But It was like 3 years ago when they developed these servers.
[/quote]
derp; and it was 5.[/quote]
Okay it was 5. Still gotta think about the time…

Read full topic

item.title: Enums
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“ytuio9`, post:21, topic:424052”]Your post got “cut o” again

Anyway, what would you use a hashmap for…[/quote]

[quote=“zyle1992, post:20, topic:424052”]Enums should be used to represent fixed data types (ie. Planets, colors, etc). Enums are constant structures and should not be changed after creation. Therefore, all pertinent data should be supplied in the constructor, and all data you want visible should have an accessor method. (Note that it is not necessary, but is accepted as the coding standard)

As Davidi2 will admit, its quite easy to abuse them. Take for example a class that deals with orientation. One could say that there are only 4 orientations, and could use an enum like so

public enum Orientation {
    NORTH,
    SOUTH,
    EAST,
    WEST;
}

At first glance, this may seem acceptable.[/quote]

And it may be, depending on your application. But what if you wanted something like North-West? You might say “Sure, I’ll just add some more element and make it look like this”

public enum Orientation {
    NORTH,
    NORTH_WEST,
    WEST,
    SOUTH_WEST,
    SOUTH,
    // ...
}

And you may think that’s fine. But what if you wanted to have “North North-West” (like in wind direction), then you would have to add even more element, and the enum becomes inappropriate for that case. Instead, you should use a class, with some predefined values

public class Orientation {
    public static final Orientation NORTH = new Orientation(0, 1);
    public static final Orientation SOUTH = new Orientation(0, -1);
    public static final Orientation EAST = new Orientation(1, 0);
    public static final Orientation WEST = new Orientation(-1, 0);

    private final int deltaX;
    private final int deltaY;

    public Orientation(final int deltaX, final int deltaY) {
        this.deltaX = deltaX;
        this.deltaY = deltaY;
    }

    public int getDeltaX() {
        return deltaX;
    }

    public int getDeltaY() {
        return deltaY;
    }
}

As for the HashMaps, some people use them to make accessing them easier. Although, accessing them shouldn’t be a problem, because enums should be used to express (in my opinion) small, finite data types. For example, planets are a good use of enums, the Periodic Table of Elements however probably isn’t.

@Taharok: I think the reason most people get NullPointerExceptions using enums is because they don’t check for nulls before using them, even though enums are still Objects. For example, if you take my NESW orientation enum, one could have a method like this

public void print(final Orientation orientation) {
    System.out.println(orientation.getDeltaX() + ", " + orientation.getDeltaY());
}

This might seem fine on the surface, but calling the method is perfectly legal, and will compile without error, and throw a NullPointerException if you call it like so

print(null);

So to fix it, you just need to add a validity clause to the beginning of the method

public void print(final Orientation orientation) {
    if (orientation == null) {
        return;
        // throw new NullPointerException("orientation cannot be null");
    }
    System.out.println(orientation.getDeltaX() + ", " + orientation.getDeltaY());
}

Read full topic

item.title: Enums
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“tyb97, post:24, topic:424052”][quote author=ytuio9` link=topic=526702.msg3837553#msg3837553 date=1322995686]
Your post got “cut o” again

Anyway, what would you use a hashmap for…
[/quote]
If you don’t use a HashMap, you will get null pointers, unless you use a different method,(thats just how I learned)[/quote]

Entirely untrue. HashMaps can store null types.

http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/util/HashMap.html

This implementation provides all of the optional map operations, and permits null values and the null key.

Most of the people that visit this site don’t know fundamental programming concepts. If you want to learn how to program, this isn’t place or community to do it. You’ll be amazed what you can start learning on other websites for a few months, and then come back to this hole.

Read full topic

item.title: Enums
item.dc:creator: @Wintercanon Wintercanon
item.description:
@Wintercanon wrote:

People use maps to bind the enumerated object to its ID. Here’s an easy example I wrote - I’m not maintaining that this is good practice though:

import java.util.HashMap;
import java.util.Map;

public enum Block {
    
    DIRT(0),
    GRASS(1),
    WATER(2, false);
    
    private final int id;
    
    private final boolean walkable;
    
    private Block(int id) {
        this(id, true);
    }
    
    private Block(int id, boolean walkable) {
        this.id = id;
        this.walkable = walkable;
    }

    public int getId() {
        return id;
    }

    public boolean isWalkable() {
        return walkable;
    }    
    
    private static Map<Integer, Block> map;
    
    static {
        map = new HashMap<Integer, Block>();
        for (Block block : values()) {
            map.put(block.getId(), block);
        }
    }
    
    public static Block getById(int id) {
        return map.get(id);
    }

}

Edit: also you could just use:

map.put(block.ordinal(), block);

If you didn’t want to manually assign each item an ID.

Read full topic
